book.summary: A murder investigation in the English village of King's Abbot, led by Hercule Poirot.

chapter.title: Parker
chapter.summary: Poirot questions the butler Parker about blackmail and Roger Ackroyd's murder, while Dr. Sheppard deals with his own indiscretion about the ring.

sequence.summary: Dr. Sheppard reflects on his potential indiscretion in revealing the discovery of the ring.

beat.summary: Sheppard's guilty conscience about spreading news of the ring.
beat.paragraph: It occurred to me the next morning that under the exhilaration produced by Tin-ho or the Perfect Winning, I might have been slightly indiscreet.

True, Poirot had not asked me to keep the discovery of the ring to myself. On the other hand, he had said nothing about it whilst at Fernly, and as far as I knew, I was the only person aware that it had been found.
I felt distinctly guilty. The fact was by now spreading through King's Abbot like wildfire. I was expecting wholesale reproaches from Poirot any minute.

sequence.summary: The joint funeral of Mrs. Ferrars and Roger Ackroyd takes place.
Poirot invites Dr. Sheppard to question Parker at his house.

beat.summary: Poirot reveals his plan to question Parker.
beat.paragraph: After it was over, Poirot, who had also been present, took me by the arm, and invited me to accompany him back to The Larches.

He was looking very grave, and I feared that my indiscretion of the night before had got round to his ears. But it soon transpired that his thoughts were occupied by something of a totally different nature.
'See you,' he said. 'We must act. With your help I propose to examine a witness. We will question him, we will put such fear into him that the truth is bound to come out.'
'What witness are you talking about?' I asked, very much surprised.
'Parker!' said Poirot. 'I asked him to be at my house this morning at twelve o'clock. He should await us there at this very minute.'

beat.summary: Poirot's grave demeanor and cryptic comment about hoping Parker is guilty.

sequence.summary: The interrogation of Parker about blackmail and his past.

beat.summary: Initial confrontation and accusation of blackmail.
beat.paragraph: On arrival at The Larches, we were informed that Parker was already there awaiting our return. As we entered the room, the butler rose respectfully.
'Good morning, Parker,' said Poirot pleasantly. 'One instant, I pray of you.'
He removed his overcoat and gloves.
'Allow me, sir,' said Parker, and sprang forward to assist him.

beat.summary: Poirot reveals his knowledge of Parker's past with Major Ellerby.
Parker admits to attempting blackmail and shows his bank-book.
beat.paragraph: 'It's true that I tried to listen that night. A word or two I heard made me curious. And Mr Ackroyd's wanting not to be disturbed, and shutting himself up with the doctor the way he did.'
'I thought that if Mr Ackroyd was being blackmailed, why shouldn't I have a share of the pickings?'

sequence.summary: Poirot and Sheppard discuss Parker's story and decide to visit the lawyer Hammond.
Poirot questions the lawyer Hammond about Mrs. Ferrars' financial transactions.

beat.summary: Hammond reveals Mrs. Ferrars paid out at least £20,000.
beat.paragraph: 'During the past year, Mrs. Ferrars has sold out certain securities, and the money for them was paid into her account and not re-invested.'
'In all, I should say the various sums totalled at least twenty thousand pounds.'
'And the penalty for murder is not a pleasant one.'

sequence.summary: Poirot and Sheppard discuss the implications of the £20,000 and possible suspects.

beat.summary: Discussion of Parker, Raymond, and Blunt as suspects.
beat.paragraph: 'It is, of course, possible that he banked the money under another name, but I am disposed to believe he spoke the truth to us.'
'That leaves us as a possibility, Raymond, or well - Major Blunt.'

sequence.summary: Lunch with Caroline and discussion of the case.

beat.summary: Caroline's vegetarian pretense and nut cutlet lecture.
Caroline presents her theory that only Flora or Ralph could be guilty.
beat.paragraph: 'As far as I can see, of the people in the house, only two could have had the chance of doing it. Ralph Paton and Flora Ackroyd.'
'And say what you will, I don't believe Ralph Paton is a murderer. A boy we've known all our lives.'

beat.summary: Poirot's monologue about moral weakness and blackmail.

sequence.summary: A telephone call announces the detention of Charles Kent in Liverpool.

beat.summary: The phone call about Charles Kent.
beat.paragraph: The telephone bell rang sharply. I went out into the hall, and took off the receiver.
'What?' I said. 'Yes. Dr. Sheppard speaking.'
I listened for a minute or two, then replied briefly.
Replacing the receiver, I went back into the drawing-room.

'Poirot,' I said, 'they have detained a man at Liverpool. His name is Charles Kent, and he is believed to be the stranger who visited Fernly that night. They want me to go to Liverpool at once and identify him.'
